thread.title: Facebook Both Wins and Loses Max Schrems Privacy Case at CJEU | Fortune

author: David Meyer
title: Facebook Both Wins and Loses Max Schrems Privacy Case at CJEU | Fortune
text:
By David Meyer 5:32 AM EST 
Facebook has lost an important EU court case to its nemesis, the Austrian lawyer Max Schrems, who wants to be able to sue the company in his home country over privacy violations. 
However, Schrems was not entirely successful, failing to win the right to sue Facebook on behalf of thousands of other consumers. 
Schrems is both a Facebook user and a long-running thorn in the social network‚Äôs side‚Äîhe was the one whose suit against the firm in Ireland led to the scrapping of Safe Harbor , a key EU-U.S. deal allowing for the transfer of people‚Äôs data across the Atlantic. 
Back in 2014, Schrems also tried to sue Facebook (fb) in Austria over its participation in the U.S. National Security Agency‚Äôs PRISM program, and what‚Äôs more, he tried to sue the company on behalf of 25,000 other Facebook users from around the world. 
Facebook claimed Schrems was a ‚Äúprofessional litigant‚Äù rather than a consumer, so he had no right to sue it in Austria under that country‚Äôs law‚ÄîFacebook‚Äôs European headquarters are in Ireland, so the company said he had to sue there instead. 
On Thursday, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), the bloc‚Äôs highest court, said that Schrems was indeed able to sue Facebook as a consumer in Austria‚Äîdespite his activities publishing books, giving lectures, fundraising and trying to act as an avatar for thousands of other Facebook users. 
The point, the court said, is that Schrems has always used his Facebook profile for primarily personal reasons. 
However, the CJEU said he could not bring the claims of all those other people along with him into his Austrian case. That essentially crushes Schrems‚Äôs hope of making pan-EU class actions a thing. 
In a statement, Facebook concentrated on that side of the ruling. 
‚ÄúToday‚Äôs decision by the European Court of Justice supports the previous decisions of two courts that Mr. Schrems‚Äôs claims cannot proceed in Austrian courts as ‚Äòclass action‚Äô on behalf of other consumers,‚Äù a spokesperson said, adding that Facebook now looks forward to ‚Äúresolving this matter.‚Äù First quick video statement on the #CJEU judgment on the Facebook lawsuit.. üòâ pic.twitter.com/IxnFylBhlt 
‚Äî Max Schrems (@maxschrems) January 25, 2018 
Schrems, meanwhile, said in a video reaction that he and his legal team would now be able to debate Facebook‚Äôs privacy policies with the company, including its transfer of personal data to the NSA, and its tracking of people‚Äôs online activities. 
Regarding the other side of the judgement, Schrems said the rejection of class-actions suits as a concept was not problematic for him, as he would now just bring a ‚Äúmodel case‚Äù against Facebook, but it was an issue for other cases involving mass corporate wrongdoings. 
Schrems also has another case against Facebook, over similar issues, pending before the CJEU‚Äîthough that one went via the Irish route . If he prevails in that case, Facebook may no longer be allowed to import anyone‚Äôs personal data from the EU to the U.S. SPONSORED FINANCIAL CONTENT
